specimen.classes package

Submodules

specimen.classes.medium module

Classes to import, handle, manipulate and save media.

class specimen.classes.medium.Compound(name=None, bigg=None, formula=None, exchange_flux=None)

Bases: object

The Compound objects describe the compounds of a Medium object.

The name, BiGG ID, molecule formula and exchange_flux in the medium are saved as attributes of the Compound objects. While not directly needed for the object, when using a Compound object as a part of a medium object, at least the formula attribute should be set.

Parameters:

  • name (string) – The name of the compound.

  • bigg (string) – The BiGG ID (without compartment e.g. ‘_e’) of the compound.

  • formula (string) – The molecule formula (without charges, e.g. NH4 for ammonia).

  • exchange_flux (double) – The exchange_flux of the compound in the medium.

Variables:

  • name (string) – The name of the compound.

  • bigg (string) – The BiGG ID (without compartment e.g. ‘_e’) of the compound.

  • formula (string) – The molecule formula (without charges, e.g. NH4 for ammonia).

  • exchange_flux (double) – The exchange_flux of the compound in the medium.

bigg_to_ex()

Tranform the BiGG ID into the BiGG ID of corresponding the exchange reactions. If not BiGG ID is found, tries to use the formula instead.

Raises:

ValueError: ‘Both bigg and formula attributes are not set, conversion not possible.’

Returns:

The BiGG ID of the corresponding exchange reactions.

Return type:

string

get_elements()

Count the chemical elements of the Compound.

Returns:

A dictionary of the chemical elements and their counts.

Return type:

dict

class specimen.classes.medium.Medium(name=None, description=None, compounds=[])

Bases: object

The Medium class objects contain the name and composition of a medium for genome-scale metabolic modelling.

Parameters:

  • name (string) – Name of the medium.

  • compounds (list of Compounds) – Name (ideally BiGG identifier) and exchange_fluxs of the compounds of the medium.

Variables:

  • name (string) – Name of the medium.

  • compounds (dict, string (identifer) as key and float (exchange_flux in mM) as value.) – Name (ideally BiGG identifier) and exchange_fluxs of the compounds of the medium.

add_compound(c)

Add a compound to the medium.

Parameters:

c (Compound) – The compound to be added.

Raises:

ValueError: ‘Neither bigg id or formula found. Cannot add to medium.’

combine(other)

Combine the medium with another medium.

Add all elements of the second medium, which keys are not in the first medium to the first one.

Returns:

The combined medium (new object).

Return type:

Medium

export_to_cobra(default_c=10.0)

Export the medium into a cobra model medium format.

Returns:

The medium in a format that can be directly set as a medium of a model.

Rytpe:

dict

get_compound_with_attribute(name=None, bigg=None, formula=None, exchange_flux=None)

Get all compounds that match certain attribute(s).

Search for compounds that have the given name/bigg/formula/exchange_flux. Default for all attributes is None, which means a skip for this attribute

Parameters:

  • name (string) – The name of the compound.

  • bigg (string) – The BiGG ID (without compartment e.g. ‘_e’) of the compound.

  • formula (string) – The molecule formula (without charges, e.g. NH4 for ammonia).

  • exchange_flux (double) – The exchange_flux of the compound in the medium.

Returns:

The compounds that match the given attributes (all!). Return an empty list if no match is found.

Return type:

list, of Compound objects

get_source_of(element)

Get the names of the compounds that are a source for a given element, meaning that the given element is found in the formula.

Parameters:

element (string) – The element to get the sources of.

Returns:

The names of the compounds that are a source of the given element.

Return type:

list of strings

has_compound(c)

Checks, if a compound is part of the medium.

The check can either be performed with a Compound object or a name of a compound.

Parameters:

c (Compound or string) – Either name or Compound to search the Medium for.

Raises:

TypeError: ‘’Unknown type for c (compound)’

is_aerobic()

Check if the medium is aerobic = contains O2.

Checks the medium for the name ‘o2’ and the formula ‘O2’

Returns:

The result of the check (True if medium is aerobic).

Rytpe:

bool

make_aerobic(c=10.0)

Make the medium aerobic (if it isn’t already) by adding O2.

Parameters:

c (double) – The exchange_flux of O2. Default is 10.0

make_anaerobic()

Make the medium anaerobic by removing elemental oxygen from it.

Removes oxygen by searching for compounds with the formula ‘O2’.

@TODO

add option: remove all additional oxygen sources, that are not needed for other elements?

remove_compound(c)

Remove a compound from the medium.

The removal can either be performed with a Compound object or the name of a compound.

Parameters:

c (Compound or string) – Either name or Compound to search the Medium for.

set_source_of(element, new_source, remove_all=False)

Set the source of an element to a given new source (Compound).

This function replaces either all old sources with the new one (remove_all=True) or just the compounds that are not the exclusive source for any ofther element (remove_all=False).

Parameters:

  • element (string) – The chemical element.

  • new_source (Compound) – The new source for the element.

  • remove_all (bool) – Option to eitherr remove all possible sources of the element or only those that serve NOT as the exclusive source for another element. Default is the latter option (set to False).

validate_for_model(model, add=False)

Validate a medium to be used for a cobra model.

Checks, if all exchange reactions created from the medium are present in the model. If not,

  • add=False: removes corresponding compounds from the medium

  • @TODO add=True: add the missing reaction (and metabolite to the model)

Add a medium to a media database file.

Parameters:

  • medium (Medium) – The medium to be added.

  • db_path (string) – Path to the database.

db (dict, {name:Medium}) – The medium dictionary.

The table.

Return type:

specimen.classes.medium.from_table(table)

Construct a medium from a table.

The table needs to have the following columns: medium,description,compound,bigg_id,formula, exchange_flux

Parameters:

table (pd.DataFrame) – The table.

Returns:

The constructed medium.

Return type:

Medium

specimen.classes.medium.import_medium_from_cobra(model)

Import a medium from a cobra model into a Medium ob object.

Parameters:

model (cobra.Model) – The cobra model.

Returns:

The imported medium.

Return type:

Medium

specimen.classes.medium.load_media_db(path=None)

Load a media database into a dictionary of media (name:medium).

The database should be a csv file with ‘;’ as seperators. The first line should be the following header: medium;description;compound;bigg_id;formula;exchange_flux

Parameters:

path (string) – The path to the database file. If None is given, reads the in-build media database.

Returns:

The media found in the database as a dictionary of names and Media.

Return type:

dict, {string:Medium}

specimen.classes.medium.model_minimal_medium(model, objective='flux', growth_rate=0.5, open_exchanges=False)

Get the minimal medium based on different objectives: - ‘flux’: find the minimal fluxes based in current medium. - ‘medium’: find the minimal number of compounds for the current medium. - ‘exchanges’: find the minimal number of compounds in a medium based on all avaiblae exchange reactions in the model. Note: there may be multiple solution for the minimisation, but only 1 will be returned

Parameters:

  • model (cobra.Model) – The model to minimize the medium for.

  • objective (string) – Objective for the minimisation task. Options listed above.

  • growth_rate (double, only for objectives medium and exchanges) – Minimum growth rate the model has to archieve.

  • open_exchanges (bool) – If set to True assigns large upper bound to all import reactions. Author’s note: setting is to true leads to an endlessly running program for me.

Raises:

ValueError: ‘Unknown objective for minimisation.’

Returns:

The medium that is a solution for the minimisation task.

Return type:

Medium

specimen.classes.medium.save_db(db, out_path)

Save a medium database (dictionary of name:Medium) into a csv file (seperator is ‘;’).

Parameters:

  • db (dict, {name:Medium}) – The medium dictionary.

  • out_path (string) – Path to the file for the output.

specimen.classes.reports module

Classes to generate, handle, manipulate and save reports.

class specimen.classes.reports.GrowthAnalysisReport(growth_sim_results=None, minimal_medium=None, auxo_results=None)

Bases: object

GrowthAnalysisReport saved the results of analyse_growth() and allows for saving and visualising the results.

Parameters:

  • growth_sim_results (dict, medium name : growth rate (optional)) – The results of specimen.classes.medium.growth_simulation()

  • minimal_medium (medium.Medium (optional)) – The minimal medium for the underlying model.

  • auxo_results (nested dict) – The results of auxotrophies_simulation().

Variables:

  • growth_rates (dict, medium name : growth rate (optional)) – The results of medium.growth_simulation()

  • minimal_medium (medium.Medium (optional)) – The minimal medium for the underlying model.

  • auxotrophy_results (nested dict) – The results of auxotrophies_simulation().

auxotrophies_table()

Tranform the auxotrophy_results attribute into a table format.

Returns:

the table (amino acids vs medium names)

Rytpe:

pd.DataFrame

growth_rates_table()

Turn the dictionary of growth rates into a DataFrame.

Returns:

The DataFrame.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame or None

save(dir)

Save the report.

Parameters:

dir (string) – Path to a directory to save the output to.

visualise_auxotrophies()

Visualise the results of the auxotrophy tests as a heatmap.

Returns:

The generate heatmap.

Return type:

plt.Figure or None

visualise_growth(unit='h')

Visualise thegrowth of the simulation results. Either the growth rates themselves can be visualised per hour or per min or the doubling times in minutes.

Parameters:

unit (string, choices ['h','min','dt']) – Determines the type of visualisation that is prodoced. Can be ‘h’, ‘min’ or ‘dt’. First two ones are the unit for the growth rate visualisation, the last one makes the doubling time graphic. Default is ‘h’.

Returns:

The visualisation.

Return type:

plt.fig

class specimen.classes.reports.ModelStatisticsReport(model_id, total_reac, total_meta, total_gene, reac_origin_counts, reac_with_gpr)

Bases: object

ModelStatisticsReport objects are used to store statistical information about a model. Additionally, this class provides functionalities to report said information.

Parameters:

  • model_id (string) – The model’s ID (its name).

  • total_reac (int) – Total number of reactions in the model.

  • total_gene (int) – Total number of genes in the model.

  • total_meta (int) – Total number of metabolites in the model.

  • reac_origin_counts (dict) – Descriptors and corresponding count for where the reactions where build from. Should be a dictionary of string and ints.

  • reac_with_gpr (int) – Number of reactions that are associated with a gene reaction rule (GPR)

Variables:

  • model_id (string) – The model’s ID the statistic is about.

  • reac (dict (string as above, int or dict as value)) – Information about the reaction objects, including “total” count, “origin” count and number of reactions “with gpr”.

  • meta (dict (string as above, int as value)) – Information about the metabolite objects, including “total” count.

  • gene (dict (string as above, int as value)) – Information about the gene objects, including “total” count.

get_statistics()

Generate a string got the statistics.

@TODO find a better format, maybe html?

Returns:

the statistics

Return type:

string

save(dir)

Save the report.

Parameters:

dir (string) – Path to a directory to save the output to.

class specimen.classes.reports.PanCoreAnalysisReport(model, core_reac=None, pan_reac=None, novel_reac=None)

Bases: object

PanCoreAnalysisReport objects are used to store, handle and present the information from the pan-core analysis (comparison of a model and a pan-core model).

Parameters:

  • model (cobra.Model) – The model the test was performed on.

  • core_reac (list, elements are cobra.Reaction) – List of reactions characterised as core.

  • pan_reac (list, elements are cobra.Reaction) – List of reactions characterised as pan.

  • novel_reac (list, elements are cobra.Reaction) – List of reactions characterised as core.

Variables:

  • model (cobra.Model) – The model the test was performed on.

  • core_reac (list, elements are cobra.Reaction) – List of reactions characterised as core.

  • pan_reac (list, elements are cobra.Reaction) – List of reactions characterised as pan.

  • novel_reac (list, elements are cobra.Reaction) – List of reactions characterised as core.

get_reac_counts()

Return a dictionary of the counts of the reactions types (core, pan, novel).

isValid(check='reaction-count')

Check if a certaing part of the analysis is valid.

Currently possible checks:
reaction-countcheck if the number of reactions in the model

equal the sum of the novel, pan and core reactions

@TODO

implements more checks

Parameters:

check (string) – Part of the report to check if it is valid. Default is ‘reaction-count’. Options are in the function description.

Raises:

ValueError: ‘Unknown string for parameter check: ‘

Returns:

True, if test was successful.

Return type:

bool

save(dir)

Save the results inside a PanCoreAnalysisReport object.

The function creates a new folder ‘pan-core-analysis’ inside the given directory and creates the following documents:

  • table_reactions.tsv : reactions ID mapped to their labels

  • visualise_reactions : donut chart of the values above

Parameters:

dir (string) – Path to a directory to save the output to.

visualise_reactions()

Visualise the results of the pan-core analysis for the reactions as a donut chart.

Returns:

The generated visualisation object (donut chart).

Return type:

matplotlib.figure.Figure

class specimen.classes.reports.PathwayAnalysisReport(total_reac=None, kegg_count=None, kegg_global=None, kegg_over=None, kegg_rest=None)

Bases: object

PathwayAnalysisReport saves the results of kegg_pathway_analysis() (see core.analysis) and allows for saving and visualising the results.

Parameters:

  • total_reac (int (optional)) – Total number of reactions in the model

  • kegg_count (int (optional)) – Number of reactions with KEGG pathway annotation.

  • kegg_global (dict(str,int)) – Identifiers and counts for the global level.

  • kegg_over (dict(str,int) (optional)) – Identifiers and counts for the overview level.

  • kegg_rest (dict(str,int) (optional)) – Identifiers and counts not match by overview and global level.

Variables:

  • total_reac (int) – Total number of reactions in the model

  • kegg_count (int) – Number of reactions with KEGG pathway annotation.

  • kegg_global (dict(str,int)) – Identifiers and counts for the global level.

  • kegg_over (dict(str,int)) – Identifiers and counts for the overview level.

  • kegg_paths (dict(str,int)) – Identifiers and counts not match by overview and global level.

save(dir)

Save the content of the report as plots.

Parameters:

dir (string) – Path to a directory to save the output to.

visualise_kegg_counts()

Visualise the amounts of reaction with and without KEGG pathway annotation.

Returns:

The generated plot.

Return type:

matplotlib.pyplot.figure

visualise_kegg_pathway(plot_type='global', label='id')

Visualise the KEGG pathway identifiers present.

Depending on the :plot_type:, different levels of pathway identifiers are plotted:

  • global: check and plot only the global pathway identifiers

  • overview: check and plot only the overview pathway identifiers

  • high: check and plot all identifiers grouped by their high level pathway identifiers. This option uses label=name, independedly of the input

  • all: check and plot all identifiers

Parameters:

  • plot_type (string) – Set the type of plot. Can be global, overview, high or existing. Default is global.

  • id (string) – Set the pathway label to identifier (ID) or actual name. Default is ‘id’, other option is ‘name’.

Returns:

The generated plot.

Return type:

matplotlib.pyplot.figure
